Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the father needs to handle the situation
Situation2: They see a swimmer struggling near the middle of the pool and need to stay vigilant to respond quickly.
Story: I was at the community pool with my son, trying to balance a rare afternoon off. As a father, I wanted to teach him right from wrong, so when I caught him slipping a candy bar into his pocket at the snack stand, my heart sank. I knew I had to address it—explain why stealing is wrong, make him apologize, and help him understand the consequences. But as I turned to him, my lifeguard instincts kicked in. Out of the corner of my eye, I saw a swimmer flailing in the deep end, their head bobbing just above the water. My training screamed at me to keep my eyes on the pool, to be ready to jump in at any second. I felt torn in two—my son needed me to guide him, but someone else might need me to save them. The weight of both responsibilities pressed down on me, and I stood frozen, caught between the demands of being a good father and a vigilant lifeguard.
